questions.text:
Match the following:
1. Workshop

A. Series of lectures on a subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions
2. Symposium B. Incorporates a variety of methods like speeches, discussions, and may last for half a day to a week.
3. Role play C. Series of meetings emphasizing individual work within the group
4. Seminar

D. Dramatization of social situations for health education
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within the group. External consultants or experts may be involved.

A symposium is a series of lectures on a selected subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions (no discussion is involved).

Role play is the dramatization of social situations for health education by those taking part in it.

Seminars are similar to conferences and incorporate a variety of methods like speeches, discussions for health education, which may last for half a day to a week.

Methods of Health Communication    
Individual approach Group approach Mass approach
  1. Personal contact
  2. Home visits
  3. Personal letters
  1. Lectures
  2. Demonstrations
  3. Discussion methods
    • Group discussions
    • Panel discussion
    • Symposium
    • Workshop
    • Conferences
    • Seminars
    • Role play
  1. TV
  2. Radio
  3. Newspaper
  4. Printed material
  5. Direct mailing
  6. Posters
  7. Health museums
  8. Health exhibitions
  9. Folk method
  10. Internet

questions.text: Evidence-based medicine refers to:

choices.text: Opinions and experiences of experts in medicine
Use of research findings for taking decisions about patient care

questions.solution:
• Evidence based medicine (EBM) is the integration of best research evidence with clinical expertise and patient values.
  • Research and studies are given high importance in EBM.
  • Opinions and conventional wisdom of experts are not taken into consideration in the practice of EBM.
  • David Sackett is called the Father of EBM.

questions.text: Mixing waste with cement, lime and other substances before transporting to a landfill is called:
questions.solution:
Inertization is the mixing of waste like pharmaceuticals with cement, lime, and water to form a homogenous paste.This is then transported and disposed at a landfill.

The ideal proportion of weight in inertization is:

  • Pharmaceuticals- 65%
  • Lime- 15%
  • Cement- 15%
  • Water- 5%

Option B: Encapsulation involves immobilizing waste like pharmaceuticals in a plastic or steel drum which is then filled with cement or sand.

Option C: Microwave irradiation is a process by which infectious waste is treated with the action of microwaves of a certain frequency.

Option D: Plasma pyrolysis is a waste treatment technique that gasifies matter in an oxygen-starved environment to decompose waste to its basic molecular structure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of sentinel surveillance?

choices.text: Indicates trends in the entire target population
Identifying cases that are free of disability

questions.solution:
Sentinel surveillance helps in identifying the missing cases among the old and new cases.

Sentinel surveillance is a method to identify the missing cases and hence supplement the notified cases.

The sentinel data collected in this type of surveillance can estimate the disease prevalence (old and new cases) in the total population. This system provides more valuable and detailed information compared to what is obtained from traditional notification systems.

In sentinel surveillance, a prearranged set of reporting sources agrees to report all the cases of a defined condition. This will indicate the trend of the disease in the entire target population.

 

Related Pearl: Sentinel Surveillance

  • Sentinel surveillance is used to augment the notification systems used in surveillance of diseases.
  • It detects the total case load and is used to identify the missing cases that are not notified among the old and new cases.
  • Sentinel data from the same is extrapolated to the entire population and the prevalence can be commented on.
  • Advantages: Bias in reporting is minimized and the feedback is simplified.

questions.text: For an epidemiological study, every 10th person from a population is selected. This type of sampling is called_______
questions.solution:
• Systematic random sampling is done by picking every 5th or 10th unit at regular intervals.
  • Simple random sampling is done by assigning a number to each of the units in the sampling frame, after which a table of random numbers are used to determine which of the units are to be included in the sample.
  • Stratified random sample is done by deliberately drawing the sample in a systematic way so that each portion of the sample represents a stratum of the universe of study.

questions.text: Discovery of transmission of malaria by Anopheline mosquitoes was by_______
questions.solution:
Ronald Ross showed that malaria was transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito.

Charles Alphonse Laveran discovered the malarial parasite.

Walter Reed showed that yellow fever transmitted by Aedes mosquito.

David Bruce showed African sleeping sickness/trypanosomiasis transmitted by the tsetse fly.

questions.text: Denominator in effective literacy rate is:

choices.text: Total population enrolled in secondary education in a given year
Total population in a given year
Total population aged 7 and above in a given year
Total population aged 16 and above in a given year

questions.solution:
Effective literacy rate= Number of literate persons aged 7 and above x 100/ Population aged 7 and above in a given year

Crude literacy rate = Number of literate persons x 100/ Total population in a given year

questions.text: Migration studies are used for studying:

choices.text: Socio-demographic reasons for migration of a population
Prevalence of diseases in a population
Environmental and genetic factors of a disease in a population

questions.solution:
Migration studies are used to evaluate the role of genetic and environmental factors of a disease in a population.

Two methods can be used:

  • Compare disease & death rates of migrants with kin who stayed at home.
  • Compare disease & death rates of migrants with local population of host country.

Limitations of these studies:

  • Non randomization of these groups.
  • Environmental factors may act only up to a certain age.
  • Not useful for diseases with long incubation periods.

questions.text: Approximate incubation period of swine flu is_______
questions.solution:
• Swine flu is caused by the influenza A virus subtype H1N1.
  • It was the cause of a pandemic that occurred in 2009.
  • Incubation period is approximately 2 to 3 days but could range up to 7 days.
  • Clinical features vary from flu like symptoms to pneumonia, severe diarrhea and cardiopulmonary insufficiency.
  • Best laboratory test is RT-PCR which is highly sensitive.
  • Oseltamivir and zanamivir are drugs most widely used for treatment of swine flu.

questions.text: Emporiatrics deals with______
questions.solution:
• Emporiatrics is also called travel medicine.
  • It deals with the prevention and management of health problems of international travelers.

questions.text: Adjuvant used in DPT is:
questions.solution:
Adsorbed DPT vaccine has aluminium phosphate or hydroxide as the mineral carrier or adjuvant, which is the most advocated preparation for immunization in infants.

DPT vaccine is a combined vaccine against diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus. It should be stored at 2 to 8 degree Celsius.

Three doses are usually given for primary immunization, intramuscularly, at 4 weeks apart. Boosters are given at 1 ½ to 2 years and then at 5 to 6 years. Fever and mild local reactions are common post-immunization.

questions.text: Which of the following is among the pillars of primary health care?
questions.solution:
Principles or pillars of primary health care include equitable distribution, community participation, intersectoral coordination and appropriate technology.

Related Pearl: Elements and Principles of Primary Health Care

A. Elements of Primary Health Care

(Mnemonic: ELEMENTS)

  • Education about health problems and their prevention and control
  • Locally endemic diseases – prevention and control
  • Essential drugs
  • Maternal and child health care
  • Expanded programme of immunization against vaccine preventable diseases
  • Nutrition and proper food supply
  • Treatment of common diseases and injuries
  • Safe water and sanitation

B. Principles/Pillars of Primary Health Care

  • Equitable distribution
  • Community participation
  • Intersectoral coordination
  • Appropriate technology

questions.text: A disease epidemic in a bird population is called______
questions.solution:
Epornithic is the term used for an epidemic disease in a bird population.

Epizootic is the term used for an outbreak (epidemic) of a disease in animal populations with the implication that it may affect human populations, like anthrax, brucellosis, Q fever, etc.

Enzootic is the term used for an endemic disease that affects the animal population regularly.

Exotic diseases are those diseases which do not occur in an area but are imported from another.

questions.text:
Which of the following are components of the physical quality of life index (PQLI)?
  1. Infant mortality rate
  2. Life expectancy at birth
  3. Literacy rate
  4. Life expectancy at 1 year of age
  5. Under 5 mortality rate
questions.solution:
Infant mortality rate, literacy rate, and life expectancy at 1 year of age are the components of the physical quality of life index (PQLI).

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

 Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI)
Components

Longevity (Life expectancy at birth)

A decent standard of living (Real GNI per capita in PPP US$)

Knowledge (mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling)

Life expectancy at 1 year of age 

Infant Mortality rate

Literacy rate
Range 0 to +1 0 to 100

questions.text: Which agency of the UN has the following logo?
questions.solution:
United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) works closely with the WHO on health matters.

UNICEF’s content of services include:

  • Child health
  • Child nutrition
  • Family and child welfare
  • Education: formal and non-formal

UNICEF participates in Urban Basic Services (UBS) with aim to promote basic services like nutrition, water supply and sanitation.

UNDP is the United Nations Development Programme. It gives funds for technical assistance. Its logo:

Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) helps nations to improve living standards by mainly influencing nutrition, farming and forestry. Its logo:

United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) mainly works in the area of family health and welfare. Its logo:

questions.text: Most difficult criterion to establish causal association in etiology of a disease is:
questions.solution:
Specificity is the most difficult criterion to establish in both chronic and acute diseases.

This is because a single factor or cause can give rise to more than one disease.

Also, most diseases are due to multiple factors with no possibility of demonstrating a one-to-one relationship which would indicate specificity.

 

Related Pearl: Hill's Criteria for Causal Association

  • It is also called Bradford Hill criteria.
  • It was established in 1965 by English epidemiologist, Sir Austin Bradford Hill.

Criteria

Brief Description

Temporality

Suspected cause precedes observed effect.

Strength

Larger the relative risk, the more likely it is causal.

Consistency

If the association is observed repeatedly under the same or various conditions, then more likely it is causation.

Specificity

When exposure is associated with a specific outcome only, then it is more likely to be causal.

Plausibility

A biologically plausible mechanism between cause and effect can be support for causation.

Coherence

A causal conclusion should not seriously conflict with the present substantive knowledge of the outcome.

Analogy

Other established cause-effect relationships may be used in analogies to support this causal relationship.

Gradient

It is called dose-response or response curve. It refers to the existence of an exposure-response relationship.

Experiment

To check if the condition can be or has been changed, weakened or prevented by experimental approach.

questions.text: What is the science which aims to improve the genetic endowment of human population by selective controlled breeding?
questions.solution:
• Eugenics is the social philosophy of hereditary improvement of the human race by controlled selective breeding.
  • Positive eugenics– encouraging breeding of those with desirable phenotypes.
  • Negative eugenics– discouraging breeding of those with undesirable phenotypes.
  • Sir Francis Galton proposed this term.
  • Dysgenics is the opposite of eugenics.
  • Euthenics is the environmental manipulation of genes.
  • Genetic counseling is a preventive measure in which parents are counseled on the risk of genetic disorders in their offspring.
  • Amniocentesis is a method of prenatal diagnosis of genetic disorders in which amniotic fluid is used for testing.

questions.text: Which is not an advantage of case control studies?
questions.solution:
• Incidence cannot be calculated from case control studies and can be done from longitudinal studies.
  • Case control studies are suitable for studying rare disease.
  • They are less time consuming and have no risk of attrition.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: All of the following are morbidity indicators except:
questions.solution:
• Work loss days is a disability indicator. 
  • Incidence, prevalence and notification rates are morbidity indicators.
  • DALY, HALE and Sullivan’s Index are other disability rates.

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Mortality Indicators

Morbidity Indicators

Universal indicators:

  • Crude death rate
  • Life expectancy
  • Age-specific death rates
  • Disease-specific mortality rate
  • Proportional mortality rate
  • Case fatality rate
  • Years of potential life lost
  • Adult mortality rate

Maternal and child-related indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Child death rate
  • Under-5 proportionate mortality rate
  • Maternal mortality rate
  • Incidence and Prevalence
  • Notification rates
  • Attendance rates at OPD
  • Admission, discharge & re-admission rates
  • Duration of stay in hospital
  • Spells of sickness or absence from work or school

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect?

choices.text: Shrivastav committee – Creation of health guides
Kartar Singh committee – Multipurpose worker scheme
Jungalwalla committee – Integration of health services

questions.solution:
• 3 Tier Rural Infrastructure and creation of village health guides were recommended by the Shrivastav committee.
  • Chadah committee proposed 1 basic health worker for a population of 10,000.
  • Kartar Singh committee proposed the multipurpose worker scheme
  • Jungalwalla committee proposed the integration of health services.

Related Pearl: Health Planning Committees of India

Year

Name

Concepts and Programmes

1946

Bhore committee
  • Also called Health Survey and Development Committee
  • 1 PHC for 40,000 population
  • 3 million plan
  • 3 months training in PSM for physicians
  • Preventive and curative services at all administrative levels 

1962

Mudaliar committee
  • Also known as Health Survey and Planning Committee
  • District hospitals to have specialists
  • 1 PHC for not more than 40,000 people
  • Constitution of All India Health Service

1963

Chadah committee
  • Outlined responsibility of PHCs in the National Malaria Eradication Programme
  • One basic health worker for 10,000 population 

1965

Mukerji committee
  • Delinked malaria activities from family planning activities.
  • Family planning assistants were for family planning work and basic health workers for other activities.

1966

Mukerji committee
  • Also called committee of Health Secretaries.
  • Detailed the Basic Health Service to be given at block level 

1967

Jungalwalla committee
  • Also called Committee on Integration of Health Services
  • Ban of private practice by government doctors
  • Equal pay for equal work and special pay for specialized work

1973

Kartar Singh committee
  • Also called Committee on Multipurpose Workers under Health and Family Planning
  • Recommended male and female health workers
  • 1 PHC for 50,000 population
  • Each PHC to have 16 sub-centres
  • Each sub-centre to have one male and one female health worker

1975

Shrivastav committee
  • Also called Group on Medical Education and Support Manpower
  • Referral Services Complex
  • Rural Health Infrastructure of Sub centre, PHC and CHC
  • ROME scheme – Reorientation of health education
  • Establishment of Medical and Health Education Commission
  • Village Health Guide scheme
  • Bands of semi–professional and Para-professional Health workers 

1983

Krishnan committee

 
  • Urban Revamping Scheme
  • Integration of PHC       

1986

Bajaj committee
  • Formulation of National Medical and Health Education Policy.
  • Formulation of National Manpower Policy.
  • Health Manpower cells
  • Education commission.

questions.text: Which of the following types of pneumoconiosis is caused by Micropolyspora faeni?
questions.solution:
• Farmer’s lung is caused by infection due to Micropolyspora faeni which is a type of thermophilic actinomycetes.
  • It is now called Saccharopolyspora rectivirgula.
  • This is commonly due to the inhalation of mouldy hay or grain dust.
  • This condition has predominantly respiratory symptoms and can cause pulmonary fibrosis.

Related Pearl: Some common pneumoconiosis

Agent

Exposure

Mineral Dusts

Coal dust

Anthracosis
Macules

Progressive massive fibrosis

Caplan syndrome

Coal mining (particularly hard coal)

Silica

Silicosis

Metal casting work, sandblasting, hard rock mining, stone cutting, others

Asbestos

Asbestosis
Pleural plaques
Caplan syndrome

Carcinoma of the lung, larynx, stomach, colon

Mining, milling, manufacturing, and installation and removal of insulation

Beryllium

Lung carcinoma (?)

Farming  

Bagasse

Bagassosis

Manufacturing wallboard, paper

Bird droppings

Bird-breeder’s lung

questions.text: Which of the following statements about rate is false?

choices.text: It measures the occurrence of an event in a population.
It has no specification of time.
It's numerator is mostly part of the denominator.

questions.solution:
Rate is the measurement of the occurrence of a particular event in a given time. Hence, rates have a specification in time.

Examples include crude death rate, incidence rate etc.

Related Pearl: Rate, Ratio and Proportion

  • Rate:
    • It measures the occurrence of a particular event in a population in a given time.
    • It consists of a numerator, denominator, time specification and multiplier.
    • Numerator is often part of the denominator.
    • Examples: Crude death rate, incidence rate.
  • Ratio:
    • It expresses a relation in size between two random quantities.
    • It consists of only numerator and denominator and no time specification.
    • The numerator is not part of the denominator.
    • Examples: sex ratio, doctor-population ratio.
  • Proportion:
    • It is a ratio that indicates the relation in magnitude of a part of a whole.
    • The numerator is always part of the denominator.
    • Proportions are usually expressed as percentage and it is often measured at a point in time.

questions.text: If 60 values are arranged in ascending order, what would be the middle value?
questions.solution: Median is the value of the middle observation when the observations are arranged in ascending order. In a distribution with even number of observations, the average of the two middlemost values is taken as the median.

questions.text: In human psychology, which of the following is not an established type of defense mechanism?
questions.solution:
Some common defence mechanisms in human psychology:

Rationalization Making excuses and giving justifications for failures in place of accepting and correcting them.
Projection Blaming another person for his/her mistakes or failures.
Compensation Compensating a failure with some other success. 
Escape mechanism Using alternative and deceptive methods to escape from a situation.
Displacement Failure in one situation influences his/her reaction in an unrelated situation.
Regression Using practices like crying and sulking in times of failure as one does in childhood.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: It is appropriate to use the GATHER approach for:
questions.solution:
The GATHER approach is mainly used for counseling (like in contraceptive counselling) in which a person is helped to make a decision about health.

Expansion:

  • G- Greet
  • A- Ask
  • T- Tell options or give answers
  • H- Help in making choices
  • E- Explain everything about the decision
  • R- Return for follow up

questions.text: The incidence of bladder carcinoma is 5 times higher in smokers than in non smokers. Based on the data given, calculate the attributable risk?
questions.solution:
• In this scenario, take the incidence among non-exposed as x and the incidence among exposed as 5x.
  • The attributable risk would be given as [(5x – x)/5x] x 100.
  • Thus, the attributable risk is 80%.
  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: Guthrie test is done in neonates for screening of:
questions.solution:
• Guthrie test is done in neonates to screen for phenylketonuria.
  • In the test, blood sample is collected by heel prick after 7-10 days of birth.
  • Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of amino acid metabolism where phenylalanine hydrozylase is deficient.
  • It causes mental retardation and seizures if not kept in check.
  • Other diseases for which neonates are commonly screened- neonatal hypothyroidism, hemoglobinopathies and congenital dislocation of hip.

questions.text: The ultimate desired state towards which objectives and resources are directed is:
questions.solution:
• Objective is the planned end point of all activities. It is a precise point.
  • Target refers to a discrete activity and permits the concept of degree of achievement.
  • Goal is the ultimate desired state towards which objectives and resources are directed. It is not constrained by time or resources.
  • Mission describes the cause of existence of the programme.
  • Impact is the positive effect of the programme leading to overall development.

questions.text:
Under the ESI Act, the covered employees contribution to the fund from the daily wages is:

ESI - Employees State Insurance
questions.solution:
The ESI is a self-financing insurance scheme in which the covered employees contribute 0.75% of the wages, whereas, the employers contribute 3.25% of the wages, payable to their employees.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: Which dietary change that is advised for prevention of coronary heart disease is incorrect?

choices.text: Reduction of salt intake to 10 grams/day or less
Reduction in dietary cholesterol to < 100 mg/ 1000 kcal/ day
Consumption of saturated fats limited to < 10% of total energy intake

questions.solution:
The dietary modifications that are recommended to prevent CHD are:

  • Reduction of fat intake to 20 to 30% of total energy intake.
  • Consumption of saturated fats limited to <10% of total energy intake.
  • Reduction in dietary cholesterol to < 100 mg/ 1000 kcal/ day.
  • Reduction of salt intake to 5 grams/day or less.
  • Increase in complex carbohydrate intake.
  • Avoid alcohol consumption.

questions.text: Systematic observation and recording of activities of one or more individuals carried out at predetermined or random intervals is:
questions.solution:
Work sampling is systematic observation and recording of activities of one or more individuals carried out at predetermined or random intervals to give quantitative measurement of the various activities.

It helps in standardizing the methods of performing the jobs and determining the need for manpower.

Management Methods in Health Programmes:

Methods based on behavioral sciences

Quantitative methods

Organisational design

Personnel management

Communication

Information systems

Management by objectives(MBO)

Cost–Benefit analysis

Cost-Effective analysis

Cost–Accounting

Input–Output analysis

Model

Systems analysis

Network analysis- Includes Programme Evaluation and Review Technique(PERT) and Critical Path Method(CPM)

Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)

Work sampling

Decision making

questions.text: In a population of 5000, new cases of TB are 500 and old cases are 150. What is the prevalence of TB in this case?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, old and new cases must be taken together as 650 total cases, thus making the prevalence of TB at 13%.

Prevalence = (Number of all cases of a disease at a given point in time/Estimated population at that time) x 100

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: Assigning to persons, group characteristics which they may or might not posses as individuals is what kind of bias?
questions.solution:
An ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

Hawthorne effect is a disadvantage of cohort studies where people change or alter their behaviour during the course of the study which affects the outcome and distorts the results.

Attrition occurs when study subjects drop out of the study during its course. It is common in cohort studies.

Berkesonian bias is due to different hospital admission rates for people with different diseases.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text:
Which of the following duties would be performed by a male health worker?
  1. Chlorination of water bodies
  2. Maintenance of eligible couple registers
  3. Distribution of conventional contraceptives
  4. Universal Immunization Program
  5. Reproductive and child health services
questions.solution:
The duties of a male health worker include chlorination of water bodies, distribution of conventional contraceptives, and reproductive and child health services.

Female health workers are responsible for preparing and maintaining the registers for eligible couples and children, as well as the Universal Programme on Immunization (UIP). Male health workers assist female health workers in preparing and maintaining the eligible couple register, maternal and child health register, and the Expanded Programme on Immunization (EPI). 

Related Pearl: Responsibilities of Health Workers

Female Health Worker

Male Health Worker

Maternal and child health services

Family planning services and registers

Medical Termination of Pregnancy

Universal Immunization Program

Detection of non communicable diseases

Dai training

Treatment of minor ailments

Participate in team activities

National Health Programmes

Malaria slides and surveillance

Leprosy follow-up

Identification and follow-up cases of blindness

Reproductive and child health services

RNTCP

Expanded Immunization Program

Environmental sanitation including chlorination of water and proper waste disposal

Common Responsibilities

Nutrition

Distribution of contraceptives

Work on communicable diseases like DOTS activities

Record and report vital events

Record keeping and maintaining registers

questions.text: The germ theory of disease stated that most diseases were caused by microorganisms. Who advanced this theory?
questions.solution:
Louis Pasteur advanced the germ theory of disease, which stated that most diseases were caused by microorganisms.

He is also known for the following contributions:

  • Disproved the theory of spontaneous generation.
  • Developed vaccines for rabies and fowl cholera.
  • Pioneer of techniques of pasteurization and sterilization.

Scientist/ Doctor

Achievements 

Susruta

Father of Indian Surgery

Father of Plastic and Cosmetic Surgery

Author of “Susruta Samhita” 

Hippocrates

First True Epidemiologist

Father of Medicine

Author of “Airs, Water and Place” 

Charaka

Father of Indian Medicine

Author of “Charaka Samhita” 

Avicenna

Author of “Canon of Medicine” and “The Book on Healing” 

Andreas Vesalius

Father of Modern Anatomy

Author of “Fabrica” 

Hammurabi

Author of “Babylonian Code of Hammurabi”

John Snow

 Father of Epidemiology

 

Louis Pasteur Robert Koch / Ferdinand Cohn

Father of Bacteriology 

Samuel Hahnemann

 

Father of Homeopathy

questions.text: The link worker scheme is part of:

choices.text: National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme
National Programme for Control of Blindness

questions.solution:
• Link worker scheme is part of the National AIDS Control Programme (NACO).
  • It is a community-based outreach strategy to address HIV prevention and care in rural populations.
  • Some components of this scheme include health education on safe practices, condom promotion, counseling, testing, referrals and follow-ups.
  • Through link workers, it aims to reduce stigma and provide support to the people living with HIV.

questions.text: In a study for the correlation between variables A and B, the coefficient of correlation arrived at was 1.1. This indicates________
questions.solution:
• The correlation coefficient ‘r’ tends to lie between values of -1.0 and +1.0.
  • In this question, the co-efficient is given as 1.1 which indicates a computational error.
  • If it is near +1, it indicates a strong positive association.
  • If it is near -1, it indicates a strong negative association.
  • If ‘r’ is 0, it indicates no association.

Coefficient of correlation is calculated to understand the linear relation between two variables.

questions.text: Wastewater without human excreta is called_______
questions.solution:
Sullage or greywater is all wastewater generated in domestic areas without fecal contamination.

Blackwater is wastewater from domestic areas that has fecal contamination.

Sewage, also called domestic or municipal wastewater is a type of wastewater produced by a community in total. It contains both blackwater and greywater (sullage).

Sludge is the organic matter that settles down in the tank during the sedimentation step of primary treatment of sewage.

questions.text: Maximum tolerated dose of a drug is evaluated in which phase of a clinical trial?
questions.solution:
Maximum tolerated dose of a new drug is tested in Phase I of a clinical trial.

Related Pearl: Phases of Clinical Trials

Phase I

(First in human)

Phase II

(First in patient)

Phase III

(Multi-site trial)

Phase IV

(Post-marketing)

10 – 100 

50 - 500 

500 - 3000

Large or according to study

Usually healthy volunteers

Patients with the target disease

Patients with the target disease

Real-world patients

Open-label study

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Usually the observational or open-label

Human pharmacology and safety: To determine safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetic parameters

Therapeutic exploration and dose-ranging: To determine efficacy and dose-ranging

 

Therapeutic confirmation and comparison: Indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. Monitoring of adverse reactions is done. 

Postmarketing surveillance: To monitor drug interactions, compliance and long-term or rare side effects

Extends from months to 1 year

1–2 years

3–5 years

Unending, after drug approval

questions.text: A screening test was carried out among 114 population and 15 had the disease. 22 showed positive tests among which 14 had the disease. What is the sensitivity of the test?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the table is

  Disease + Disease - Total
Test + 14 (TP) 8 (FP) 22
Test - 1 (FN) 91 (TN) 92
Total 15 99 114

Sensitivity is given as TP/(TP + FN) x 100.

Thus sensitivity is 93.3%.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Most commonly reported disease in the post-disaster period is:
questions.solution:
Gastroenteritis is the most commonly reported after a disaster.

Supply of safe drinking water and proper disposal of excreta is most practical and effective strategy of disease prevention and control in post – disaster phase.

Other diseases common in the post – disaster phase are acute respiratory infections, leptospirosis, rickettsiosis, rabies, equine encephalitis.

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive from the picture:
questions.solution:
Vaginal sponges are barrier methods of contraceptive which are saturated with 1000mg of spermicide usually nonoxynol-9.

Female condoms are also barrier methods and have the added benefit of STD prevention.

Vaginal diaphragms are also called Dutch caps and are always used alongside a spermicidal jelly.

Vaginal rings usually contain levonorgestrel and it is absorbed slowly through the vaginal mucosa.

questions.text: Drug of abuse called ‘superman drug’ is:
questions.solution:
• Amphetamines are called superman drugs in context of drug abuse as they give a tremendous boost to self confidence and increase endurance.
  • Abuse of this drug causes psychic dependence and can cause tolerance.
  • Tobacco is the most abused legal, addictive substance in India.

questions.text: An area is declared free of an epidemic disease when:

choices.text: No cases are reported for one incubation period of the disease
Surveillance reports for 1 year reveal no cases
Surveillance reports of 6 months reveal no cases
No cases are reported for twice the incubation period of the disease

questions.solution:
An area is declared free of an epidemic when there are no cases reported for twice the incubation period of the disease.

Elimination refers to the Reduction to zero (or a very low defined target rate) of new cases of an infectious disease in a defined geographical area as a result of deliberate efforts; continued measures to prevent re-establishment of transmission are required. refers to the reduction to zero (or a very low defined target rate) of new cases in a defined geographical area(WHO definition).

questions.text: The Hardy-Weinberg law is not affected by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Random mating does not affect the Hardy-Weinberg Law.

Mutation, small populations and gene outflow can cause failure of this law.

Related Pearl: Hardy-Weinberg Law

  • The Hardy-Weinberg Law is related to population genetics.
  • It is based on the principle founded by G.H. Hardy and Wilhelm Weinberg.
  • The law states that the relative frequencies of each gene allele tends to remain constant from generation to generation in the absence of other evolutionary influences.
  • It is also called the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium or principle.
  • It is only applicable for infinitely large, static populations which randomly mate.
  • This law fails in the following conditions:
    • Small and dynamic populations
    • Non random or assortative mating
    • Mutations
    • Gene outflow and genetic drift
    • Migration

questions.text: An effective prevention program resulted in a 90% decrease in the prevalence of a disease in a community. What change would be seen in the characteristics of the screening test?

choices.text: Its negative predictive value has increased
Its positive predictive value has increased
There is no change in the test’s characteristics

questions.solution:
Negative predictive value (NPV) of a test is inversely proportional to the prevalence of a disease.

If the prevalence falls, the NPV is increased.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: ORS contains 75 mmol/L of_______
questions.solution:
WHO Reduced osmolarity ORS

Sodium chloride 2.6 grams/litre
Glucose, anhydrous 13.5 grams/litre
Potassium chloride 1.5 grams/litre

Total weight 20.5 grams/litre

questions.text: Which of the following is true about triage during the disaster?
questions.solution:
• In triage, green is low priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses.
  • Red is a high priority or transfer; yellow is medium priority and black is dead or moribund patients.
  • Triage consists of rapidly classifying the injured in a disaster on the basis of severity of injury and the likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention.
  • It is done at the site of the disaster.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: In 1986, the COPRA was instated in India. This legislation is related to:
questions.solution:
Consumer Protection Act or COPRA was instituted in 1986 and deals with consumer rights.

It recognizes six rights of the consumers, which are

  • Right to safety
  • Right to be informed
  • Right to be heard
  • Right to choose
  • Right to seek redressal
  • Right to consumer education

questions.text: What does bimodality in person distribution refer to?

choices.text: Description of two etiological hypotheses of a disease in one person
Evaluation of two different environmental factors of a person in disease causation
Two separate peaks in the age incidence curve of a disease
Equal incidence of a disease in male and female population

questions.solution:
Bimodality refers to the occurence two separate peaks in the age incidence curve of a disease.

Example: Hodgkin's lymphoma shows a bimodal curve with peaks at 15–20 years and 70–80 years.

The image below shows bimodality in the age incidence curve:

questions.text: In inventory management of drug stores, analysis done for expenditure of large proportions for small numbers and vice versa is called_______
questions.solution:
• ABC classification is a method of inventory management especially in drug stores and pharmacies.
  • In this system, the monetary values of the annual consumption of all the items in the inventory is done and are analyzed for expenditures of large proportions on a small number of items and vice versa as A, B or C.
  • This makes it easier to understand how to control the majority of expenditure by analyzing the small numbers of items it is being spent on.

The table below explains ABC analysis:

Category Percentage of items Percentage of overall value
Class A item 5-25% 40-80%
Class B itemss 20-40% 15-40%
Class C items 40-75% 5-20%
  • VED stands for vital, essential and desirable, which is also used in drug store management
  • Critical path method (CPM) and Performance Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT) are types of network analysis used in health management.

questions.text: The number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group in a given year is:
questions.solution:
• General fertility rate (GFR) is the number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group in a given year.
  • GFR = [(Number of live births in an area during year) / (Mid-year female population in reproductive age of 15-44 in same area in same year)] x 100
  • It is a good measure of fertility but its disadvantage is that not all women in that area in the reproductive age group would have been exposed to childbirth.
  • Total fertility rate is the sum of the age-specific fertility rates of women in each five-year age group from 15 to 44 or 49 years.
  • Gross reproduction rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming there is not mortality.
  • Net reproduction rate is the number of daughter a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about vaccine vial monitors (VVM)?

choices.text: It measures the cumulative heat exposure through a color change
A standard type of VVM is chosen for all vaccine vials
It helps in reducing vaccine wastage
VVM doesn’t measure exposure to freezing temperatures

questions.solution:
4 types of vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are present and are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccines based on the VVM number: 

  • VVM 30: High stability
  • VVM 14: Medium stability
  • VVM 7: Moderate stability
  • VVM 2: Least stable

VVM are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain. It records cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color (Option A). If the color of the inner square is the same or is darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to high temperatures and should be discarded. VVMs do not measure exposure to freezing temperatures (Option D).

Purpose of VVMs:

  • Ensures that vaccines damaged by heat are not administered.
  • Decision on which vaccines to be kept after a cold chain break occurs, minimizing unnecessary vaccine wastage (Option C).
  • Decision on which vaccine is to be used first. Vaccines showing significant heat exposure should be used before those that show lower heat exposure, even if their expiry date is longer.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: A randomized control trial showed an effective treatment against a chronic disease and it was then incorporated by a hospital. Which of the following is subsequently expected to happen?
questions.solution:
A new effective treatment for a chronic disease would reduce the duration of the disease, thereby reducing prevalence.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: What is the minimum number of beds required in a community health center?
questions.solution:
The minimum number of beds in a CHC is 30.

The following manpower must be maintained at a CHC: 

Personnel and Strength at CHCs
Medical
  1. General duty MO (6 - at least 2 female doctors)
  2. Public health manager (1)
  3. General surgeon (1)
  4. Physician (1)
  5. OBG (1)
  6. Pediatrician (1)
  7. Anesthetist (1)
  8. Dental surgeon (1)
  9. Ophthalmologist (1 for 5 CHCs)

  11. AYUSH specialist (1)

Total: 15/16
Nursing
  1. Staff nurse (19)
  2. Public health nurse* (1)
  3. ANM* (1)

*Appointed through ASHA scheme
Paramedical
  1. Pharmacist (3)
  2. AYUSH Pharmacist (1)
Support staff
  1. Lab technician (3)
  2. Radiographer (2)
  3. Ophthalmic assistant (1)
  4. Dresser (2)
  5. Ward boys/Nursing Orderly (5)
  6. Accountant (1)
  7. OT technician (1)
  8. Statistical assistant (2)
  9. Registration clerk (2)
  10. OPD attendant (1)
  11. Group D staff (19)
