questions.text: Identify this arthropod known to transmit endemic typhus:
questions.solution:
Rat fleas are known to transmit bubonic plague, endemic typhus and chiggerosis (tropical typhus).

Sandflies transmit diseases like kala-azar.

Tsetse flies transmit trypanosomiasis or sleeping sickness.

Reduviid bugs transmit Chagas’ disease and are also called cone-nose bugs/kissing bugs/ assassin bugs/vampire bugs.

questions.text: A place where children are kept in care of a doctor and a psychiatrist is:
questions.solution:
Remand homes are places where children are kept under the care of a doctor and a psychiatrist and other skilled professionals.

Orphanages or shelter homes houses children who do not have a family or home and children, who for some reason, can’t be cared for by their parents.

Borstals accommodate boys over 16 years old who are too difficult to be handled in a certified school or those who have been sent out of them.

Foster homes are arrangements for temporary living for orphans and abandoned children whereby unknown people or distant relatives take care of them and their needs.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017?

choices.text: Advance directive rights of the mentally ill
Procedure for admission, treatment and discharge of the mentally ill

questions.solution:
Establishing mobile mental health camps for the benefit of mentally ill patients is not included under the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017.

This act encourages the mobilization of resources to improve mental health care across the country as well as reduce stigma and improve social inclusion/support for those with mental illness. It also has provisions to improve outcomes and protect their rights.

The provisions of this act include:

  • Rights of persons with mental illness to access health care, live without discrimination and enjoy confidentiality.
  • Advance directives to allow mentally ill people to make decisions about their treatment 
  • Procedures for admission, treatment (behavioral and interpersonal therapy, medications), and discharge 
  • Decriminalizing suicide and prohibiting electroconvulsive therapy unless anesthesia is used

The act also has clear instructions for the central and state mental health authorities and other mental health establishments on their endeavors.

questions.text: A Ph.D. scholar is preparing to do a prospective cohort study for association of H. pylori in IBD from the gastroenterology wards. Which of the following is most appropriate for him/her to do?

choices.text: Enroll all patients taking proton pump inhibitor
Exclude all patients with diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease
Exclude all patients with positive urea breath test for H. pylori
Enroll all patients on whom endoscopy was done

questions.solution:
• Cohort studies progress from cause to effect.
  • The study begins before the disease under study has occurred.
  • In this scenario, patients who already have the diagnosis of IBD are excluded.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about tuberculosis and diabetes?

choices.text: Higher risk of TB relapses in co-existence of TB and diabetes
Higher risk of progress from latent to active TB in diabetics
Same duration of TB drug regimen to be given for diabetics as non – diabetics
All diabetics starting TB therapy should also start insulin therapy at some point

questions.solution:
• Diabetes is an independent risk factor for tuberculosis.
  • There is higher risk of progressing from latent to active TB due to immune system being weakened by diabetes.
  • The risk of death during TB treatment is higher in diabetics with TB infection as is the risk of relapse.
  • Screening for diabetes is important in areas with high TB prevalence.
  • Duration of treatment of daily regimen for TB should be the same in diabetics as in non-diabetics.
  • Proper care of diabetes when TB co-exists is emphasized to prevent further infections and complications.

questions.text: Seasonal trend is_________

choices.text: Occurrence of a disease in cyclical pattern spread over short duration of time
Occurrence of a disease in cyclical pattern spread over a long duration of time
Occurrence of a disease in seasonal variation that is influenced by environment
Long term periodic fluctuation in a particular direction

questions.solution:
Seasonal trend is a type of periodic fluctuation. It is the occurrence of a disease in seasonal variation influenced by the environmental conditions like climate, rainfall, life cycle of vectors, heat, etc.

Examples are measles in early spring, respiratory infections in winter and heatstroke in summer.

questions.text: Permanent hearing loss occurs on continuous exposure to noise above:
questions.solution:
Permanent hearing loss results when there is continuous exposure to noise around 100 decibels (dB).

Exposure to noise above 160 dB can cause rupture of the tympanic membrane leading to permanent hearing loss.

Acceptable noise levels in India:

Area Day time Night time
Industrial area  75 70
Commercial area  65 55
Residential area  55 45
Silence zones like around hospitals, schools and religious buildings.  50 40

questions.text: Which of the following is true with regards to the following table?

choices.text: Sensitivity is the same as specificity
PPV is the same as NPV

questions.solution:
In this scenario, sensitivity is 92% and specificity is 43%

PPV = 75% and NPV = 75%.

The PPV is the same as the NPV in this scenario.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan?
questions.solution:
Swachh Bharat Abhiyan was launched in 2014.

It aims to eradicate open air defecation by the year 2019 through the construction of 12 million toilets.

The two sub-missions are Swachh Bharat Mission Gramin (SBM-G) and Swachh Bharat Mission – Urban (SBM-U).

Components of this mission include:

  • Household toilets including improving unsanitary latrines
  • Community toilets
  • Public toilets
  • Solid waste management
  • IEC and public awareness
  • Capacity building and administrative & office expenses

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening?

choices.text: Pap smear in 40 year old females
Screening of immigrants in a country
Screening for urine sugar in 40 year old males

questions.solution:
Prospective screening is done for control of a disease and usually for the benefit of others like screening immigrants for infectious diseases like tuberculosis and syphilis.

Prescriptive screening is done for case detection and people are screened for their own benefit like neonatal screening and Pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.

Testing for urine sugar in men over 40 would also be prescriptive screening.

questions.text: HIV post-exposure prophylaxis should be started within_______
questions.solution:
Post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV should be started within 72 hours of exposure after a risk assessment.

In the PEP regimen as per WHO (2016) recommendations, two antiretroviral drugs are sufficient but three are preferred.

Backbone regimen for adults and adolescents- tenofovir + lamivudine or emitricitabine.

Backbone regimen for children 10 years or below- zidovudine + lamivudine.

PEP should be taken for 28 days and strict adherence must be followed.

Follow up testing for HIV must be done 3 months after the exposure.

questions.text: In a double blind trial:

choices.text: Both observer and group being observed are blinded
Both observer and analyser are blinded
The group, observer and analyser are all blinded

questions.solution:
Blinding is done to reduce bias and other problems that may arise during studies, especially in RCTs.

Types:

  • In single blind trials, only the participants or group members are not aware of the group allocation.
  • In double blind trials, both the group members and the observers are not aware of the group allocation.
  • In triple blind trials, the group members, the observers and the analyzers are unaware of the group allocation.

The most commonly used type of blinding is double blinding.

questions.text: A researcher studied an epidemic in  Africa. Symptoms of the disease were fever, muscle pain, and bleeding. The virus is shown in the image below. What is the organism?
questions.solution:
The organism is the Ebola virus as the image shows a long thread-like filamentous virus. 

The Ebola virus is an emerging infectious disease seen in Africa which belongs to the Filoviridae family with single-stranded RNA.  Its incubation period is 2 to 21 days.  Transmission is through contact with infectious bodily fluids or organs of infected animals like chimpanzees, monkeys, fruit bats, etc. Human to human transmission is through the blood or body fluids of a symptomatic infected person.

Patients with Ebola virus infection present with fever, intense weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, and in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding. Treatment is mainly supportive with intensive support and care to reduce mortality. 

Other options: 

Option A: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is a global pandemic and it is transmitted sexually, through blood contact, or from mother to child. It is a spherical enveloped virus and belongs to retroviridae family. The clinical features are unexplained diarrhea, fever, fatigue, weight loss, etc.  

Option B: Zika virus is a spherical virus transmitted by Aedes aegypti, and is mainly seen in American countries. The symptoms are fever, skin rashes, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, etc. Association has been reported with microcephaly and Guillain-Barre syndrome. 

Option D: H1N1 is also known as pandemic influenza A or swine flu. It is a spherical virus and was spread throughout the world in 2009. The symptoms are fever, cough, and gastrointestinal diseases in uncomplicated influenza. It involved the respiratory, central nervous system, multiorgan failure and septic shock in complicated influenza.  

Related Pearl: Important Shapes of Some Viruses

VIRUS

SHAPE

Rabies virus

Bullet shaped

Pox virus

Brick shaped

Tobacco mosaic virus

Rod shaped

Ebola virus

Filamentous

Astro virus

Star shaped

Adenovirus

Space vehicle shaped

Rotavirus

Wheel shaped

 

Related Pearl: Bioterrorism Agents

Description Characteristics Examples
Category A

High priority agents

Easily disseminated

High mortality rate

Capacity to get disseminated

Social disruption

Requires specialised public health resources

 

Bacillus anthracis

Clostridium botulinum

Yersinia pestis

Variola major

Francisella tularensis

Ebola and other hemorrhagic fevers

Lassa fever and other arenaviruses

 
Category B 

Minority priority agents

Moderately well disseminated

Moderate morbidity and low mortality

Require enhancement of CD and diagnostic capacity

Coxiella burnetti

Burkholderia mallei

Burkholderia pseudomallei

Ricin toxin

Cryptosporidium parvum

Salmonella typhi

Chlamydia psittaci
Category C

Low priority agents

Could be engineered for mass dissemination

Readily available

Easy to produce

Potentially high morbidity and mortality

 Emergent viruses -Nipah and Hantavirus

Related Pearl: WHO clinical staging of HIV

Selected conditions & respective clinical stages in HIV  
Clinical stage 1
  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy
Clinical stage 2 (Mild Symptoms)
  • Moderate unexplained weight loss (<10% ofpresumed or measured body weight) 
  • Recurrent respiratory tract infections (sinusitis,tonsillitis, otitis media, pharyngitis) 
  • Herpes zoster       
  • Angular cheilitis       
  • Recurrent oral ulceration       
  • Papular pruritic eruption       
  • Fungal nail infections       
  • Seborrhoeic dermatitis       
  • Unexplained persistent hepatosplenomegaly*       
  • Extensive wart virus infection*       
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum*       
  • Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement*

 *In Children

Clinical stage 3 & 4 represent Advanced & Severe illness respectively

For complete staging, please refer WHO guidelines.

questions.text: A family in which all members play a part in its management is called______
questions.solution:
Communal family is where all the members play a part in the family’s management. It is part of the idea of a modern family and follows the philosophy of division of labor.

Joint families are also called extended families and they have a number of related families sharing the same roof, their properties and income with usually one patriarchal head.

Nuclear families are also called elementary families which consist of only a married couple and their offspring.

Three generation family is a family where there are representatives from three generations who are related by direct descent.

questions.text: In a normal delivery, breastfeeding must be ideally started:
questions.solution:
• Breastfeeding must be initiated within the 1st hour of delivery.
  • It aids in mother-child bonding and also the first drops of milk, called colostrum, have high nutritional value for the neonate.

questions.text: Phosphatase test is done to check for_______
questions.solution:
Phosphatase test is done to check the efficiency of milk pasteurization.

This test is based on the fact that raw milk has an enzyme called phosphatase which is destroyed on heating.

Other methods of checking efficiency of milk pasteurization are standard plate count and coliform count.

questions.text: Identify this instrument used to measure humidity
questions.solution:
A sling psychrometer is also called a whirling psychrometer. It consists of two mercury thermometers (wet and dry) which are used for charting the relative humidity of the air.

Dry and wet bulb hygrometer is the most widely used for measuring humidity.

Assmann psychrometer is a portable device used for humidity measurement.

questions.text: A scatter diagram is drawn to study:

choices.text: Mean and median values of extrapolated data

questions.solution:
• Scatter plots are types of statistical maps which are used to study the correlation between two given variables.
  • In scatter plots or scatter diagrams, the pattern made by plotted points along the two axes indicates possible relationship.
  • If the dots cluster along a straight line, then the relationship is of a linear nature.
  • If there is no cluster, then there might be no relationship at all.

Below is an example of a scatter diagram

questions.text: A couple has 4 children, all vaccinated for measles. A child got measles on 5th August 2015. Two other children developed measles by 15th August 2015. The secondary attack rate here is____
questions.solution:
Secondary attack rate = ( Number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period/ Total number of exposed or susceptible contacts )x 100

In this scenario, there is one primary case. The total exposed contacts are the other 3 children. Number of persons developing the disease is 2.

Thus the secondary attack rate here is 66%.

Note: Even though the children are vaccinated, they are still the exposed. The secondary attack rate does not only take into account the susceptible members but also the exposed ones.

questions.text: The most effective test for detecting sanguinarine is______
questions.solution:
Sanguinarine is a toxic alkaloid present in argemone oil which is a common contaminant of mustard oil.

Paper chromatography is the most effective test for detecting sanguinarine.

Nitric acid test is also used for this purpose.

Methylene blue reduction test is used to detect micro-organisms in milk.

Epidemic dropsy is caused by this alkaloid as it causes pyruvic acid to accumulate in the blood. Features of epidemic dropsy include diarrhea, swelling of legs, dyspnea, cardiac failure and death.
